pullRequest.title: Add permissions to AndroidManifest by scanning Attach services

commit.message: Add permissions to AndroidManifest by scanning Attach services

nodes.bodyText:
We had Glisten/Attach logic in Substrate in the past, and while that worked fine, we moved towards removing any external dependency, by using META_INF/Substrate as a way to allow any third party (JavaFX/Glisten/Attach...) pass configuration files to Substrate.
While this can be a complex task, I'd say we move this to each Attach service, using an xml file with the content that should be added to the final AndroidManifest.xml/Info.plist.
Like:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<permissions>
     <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION"/>
</permissions>

This will be more flexible to include other nodes, like extra activities or services.
Does this make sense?
Then, in Substrate, we will scan these files, and combine them properly to produce the manifest/plist.

commit.message:
Revert "Add permissions to AndroidManifest by scanning Attach services"

This reverts commit f7ef5c33
Add permissions to AndroidManifest by scanning for android-permissions.txt in Attach jars

nodes.bodyText:
I assume the third party jar (usually Attach) will have a file with lines like:
<uses-permission a:name="android.permission.CAMERA"/>

right?
However, I'd say it should only hold the permission itself:
android.permission.CAMERA

And Substrate will provide the format: <uses-permission a:name=" + line + "/>
This has the advantage of not adding a dependency of the namespace (a) to those jars.
It is probably necessary to return a list/set of permissions that are not duplicated. There is no guarantee that the jars won't contain duplicates, so probably this is a good place to enforce that?
